Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Replication Protein A Modification-Dependent Function in Mitosis and Meiosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Proper replication and maintenance of the DNA genome is essential for cell growth, function, and viability. When cells are exposed to environmental stresses that damage DNA, pathways for repairing the DNA damage are induced. One key player in this damage control is Replication Protein A (RPA), a complex of three proteins that serves as a "bridge" between damaged DNA and the machinery needed to repair the damage. In this capacity, RPA has the potential to interact with many proteins, but how specificity of those interactions is determined is not clear. One idea is that stress-induced phosphorylation of RPA mediates differential interaction between RPA and various proteins involved in DNA repair. This research will test that hypothesis by identifying which amino acid residues in the RPA proteins are phosphorylated, how phosphorylation affects physical interactions between RPA and different protein partners, and what impact RPA phosphorylation has on the ability of cells to maintain proper growth and viability. The research will be carried out in baker's yeast, which is amenable to both genetic and biochemical manipulation and is accessible to researchers of all skill levels. Because RPA is highly conserved (from yeast to human), the research findings will advance understanding of how eukaryotes coordinate DNA repair processes for maintaining genome integrity and cellular viability.

Broader Impacts: Centered at North Dakota State University, this project will contribute to learning and research opportunities science for college students in rural North Dakota and surrounding states by: improving molecular biology course content; expanding educational opportunities for non-traditional students through development of distance-learning courses in molecular biology, cell biology, genetics and biochemistry; providing opportunities for undergraduate students to conduct hands-on laboratory research; and providing a pipeline for interested students to obtain master's degrees as prerequisite for entering a new doctoral research program in STEM education. By fostering student literacy in science, this project will enable North Dakota State University to produce graduates with a solid scientific foundation that could positively impact their future contributions to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organisms continually face environmental and intracellular challenges that result in the damage of the DNA in their cells. If left unchecked or inadequately repaired, DNA damage can result in permanent changes in genetic information (i.e., mutations) that can ultimately lead to cellular, tissue, or organ dysfunction, significantly impairing the livelihood of the organism. The three-subunit complex, Replication Factor A (RFA), is critically involved through recognition of single-stranded DNA intermediates produced during the DNA damage response (DDR) and its ability to recruit other factors that provide enough time for repair to occur and/or directly repair the DNA. The project goals were to gain an understanding of how and where RFA is modified, under what context(s) it is modified, the function of each modification, and mechanistically how these modifications serve the purpose of maintaining the integrity of genetic information. The intellectual merit of this project was the discovery that modifications to specific residues of Rfa1 and Rfa2 subunits function in cell cycle control, and not necessarily DNA replication or repair directly, which is a very significant contribution to the field.

 

 Upon DNA stress, cells trigger a cell cycle stoppage (i.e., checkpoint arrest) to provide time for DNA repair. Ideally, cells should only exit this arrest if they (1) have repaired the DNA properly or (2) cannot repair the DNA and need to make a "last-ditch" effort to survive. We identified a novel yeast Rfa2 subunit phosphorylation event that requires the Rfa2 amino-terminus, is dependent on prolonged DNA damage (Figure 1) and on the key regulator of the DDR, Mec1 (ATR; Figure 2), and plays a significant role in the cellular decision to exit a checkpoint and re-enter the cell cycle (i.e., Rfa2 phosphorylation promotes exit; Figure 3). This checkpoint exit function identified in yeast can mechanistically explain all previous phenotypes observed for human Rfa2 phospho-mutants and explain phosphorylated Rfa2's likely function in human cells, where this modification has been correlated with severity of cellular disease. We also discovered that non-phosphorylation modifications are critical for the other half of checkpoint function, checkpoint entry (i.e., the cellular decision to stop the cell cycle in the first place; Figure 4). The results of this project definitively support a dual-regulation model where RFA modifications coordinate its function in regulating checkpoint arrest, from beginning (entry) to end (exit). In this model, Rfa1 lysine modifications not only promote checkpoint entry (Figure 4A), but Rfa2 lysine modifications also work simultaneously to prevent Rfa2 phosphorylation and inhibit checkpoint exit (Figure 4B). Subsequently, Rfa2 phosphorylation overcomes the effects of Rfa1 and Rfa2 lysine modifications to release the cells from the checkpoint and allow cell cycle re-entry (Figure 5). These modifications may also coordinately regulate one another. In meiosis, the Rfa2 region that is phosphorylated appears to function during the mitotic-like equational division, suggesting a similar checkpoint function role during meiosis.

 

The broader impacts of this project addressed the state of molecular biology instruction and research at North Dakota State University (NDSU) and in the region. This project addressed the limited resources and opportunities to perform cutting-edge molecular biology research at NDSU. Included in this project was support for improving the only basic molecular biology lab course offered on campus. To this end, the lab has been moved to a larger, recently renovated space, new equipment has been supplied through project funds and through matches by the department, and more current, cutting-edge technologies are now employed. This recombinant DNA technology course has grown from simple DNA amplification and cloning techniques into a semester-long independent research project involving gene mutation/knockout in an organism, as well as genotyping, and gene expression analyses. The technology used for gene manipulation, CRISPR-Cas9, involves both basic and complex recombinant DNA technologies, and this course curriculum has even been presented at a biotechnology symposium (Figure 6). It is the only molecular biology class providing this type of experience to all students pursuing the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB) major at NDSU. Furthermore, we are unaware of any other courses offered in the region that provide this type of hands-on experience to all interested students and not just through individual independent research experiences. This project has also been helpful in supporting NDSU's acceptance as one of 84 schools accredited by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB). Beyond the classroom, this project has provided training to seven graduate students, two of which have entered the biotechnology workforce, three of which are currently in training, and all of which have presented their work to national and international audiences. With respect to undergraduate training, this project has provided opportunities to nearly twenty students, many who have gone on to postgraduate education in medicine, biomedical and agricultural molecular biology research, and even in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) education research, and will become professional STEM members contributing to the community.
